awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Towards a Paradigm Shift in Data Acquisition for Traffic Control
awd_abstract_narration:
The process of collecting traffic data has long been considered as one of the important components of a city, because traffic data are used not only for traveler information systems but also as an input to support traffic control on urban streets. In the foreseeable future, we envision that in a smart and connected city the current roadway-based infrastructure for traffic data collection, such as loops, microwave sensors, or laser detectors, will be replaced by vehicle-based data. Such a paradigm shift would result in significant cost savings as well as the generation of a new form of traffic data that is more powerful than the existing one. It will make our traffic management systems more efficient and our cities more livable. The aim of this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to expedite the process that would lead to such a paradigm shift. The project envisions a system in which drivers interact with traffic control by providing their time-dependent speed and positioning information to the system as "votes" in exchange for possible priority service. Involving system users in system control through "voting" will engender interest in cutting-edge systems engineering techniques, especially for K-12 students. 

The research will provide significant advances in understanding opportunities for traffic management systems in smart and connected communities, where interaction between traffic control and individual drivers is practicable. Such interaction, a feature currently available only to special-class vehicles, would fundamentally change conventional theory for algorithm development. It could impact user-equilibrium and system optimum theories that govern route choice behavior of drivers and optimal system control at the network level. This project explores a new class of algorithms that directly utilize spatial data, as opposed to spot data used currently, to support traffic control algorithms. The new algorithms will differ from existing ones in that "qualitative information" about traffic states will be employed as an input to traffic control (e.g. "a very long queue" instead of the actual queue length). Such information can be readily inferred from speed and positioning data of individual vehicles. The interaction between individual vehicles and system control will provide system users with opportunities to inform the system of the value of their trips. Such capabilities will engender a need to rethink user equilibrium and other models of travel behavior.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we have explored some theoretical and technical issues associated with a novel traffic system in which individual drivers may voluntarily provide their time-dependent driving information to the system in exchange for a possible favorable service from traffic control. The key element of such a system is the interaction between individual vehicles and traffic control.  The focus of our research is thus on assessing the quality of traffic data provided by individual drivers for traffic control, examining the feasibility of using individual vehicle data as input for traffic control algorithms, and quantifying the resulting benefits.

On the theoretical side, we have quantified the gains and losses of individual users or user groups resulting from a change from the user equilibrium state to the system optimum state. We examine the efficiency loss in the context of a generalized highway cost function with a range of parameters comparable to those used in the BPR function. Our result shows that the percent gain through mitigating the efficiency loss is a decreasing function of the total demand in the steady state. The gain would sharply decrease after the network becomes saturated and diminish as the demand increases further. This property can be utilized to implement the interaction between individual users and traffic control, considering the range of traffic conditions for which the implementation of traffic control to mitigate the negative effect of efficient loss is the most beneficial. We introduce the concept of “priority routes” which incorporates “value of trips” of individual users into the process of highway resource allocation. 

We have also developed a vector-based demand representation for individual users with non-homogeneous perceptions of costs for characterizing the willingness-to-pay (WTP) of individual users.  In our framework, both the actual system costs and the perception of costs of users are represented by vectors in a coordinate system. In particular, the system cost, with different cost components (e.g. time, money, safety, reliability, comfort, etc.), is represented by a vector in the Cartesian coordinate, while the perceptions of the costs of users are represented by the same vector with different cost components in some user-specific coordinate systems through transformation. These cost components can be considered either separately, if the coordinates are orthogonal to each other, or jointly, if otherwise. The WTP of each individual user is also defined with respect to the user-specific coordinate system instead of the cartesian system. Our results show that the outcome of some important performance measures, such as the economic benefit, would change when different cost components for individual users are captured in detail.

For developing methodologies for the interaction between traffic control and individual users, we have performed the analysis of using positioning and speed information of individual vehicles as input data to control algorithms. Our study reveals that these data can be utilized to effectively infer spatial information of arrivals at signalized intersections even. Consequently, the traffic signal control problem can be turned into a queue management problem in which green time allocation can be made based on the ratio of queues from different approaches. Our results show that 1) reasonable accurate estimation of the queue ratio can be obtained under a rather moderate market penetration level; 2) for individual drivers, those who provide spatial information to the system for traffic control tend to benefit more than those who do not in terms of the delay experienced; 3) the queue ratio estimation using vehicle-based data is rather robust for queue length estimation; and 4) the performance of the quasi-dynamic scheme using vehicle-based data perform reasonably well with data from individual vehicles.

We have also developed a combined model based on multiple congestion metrics, each of which represent a specific aspect of traffic congestion.  The combined model is comprised of the Normalized Scoring Method (NSM), Principal Component Analysis (PCA), and the similarity measure based on the Proportion Discordance Ratio (PDR).  From each of the three proposed methodologies for the combined model, scores are obtained for all entities, and the combined model outputs a final set of ranking based on these scores.  The numeric analysis shows that the overall results based on the combined model are more realistic than the ones based on only one method.  This methodology is capable of measuring traffic congestion levels more objectively, especially when data from individual travelers becomes available since a sample dataset collected from individual travelers is more representative of the general population of drivers, and the analysis based on this dataset would be less biased.  The combined model we proposed can be applied to new data sources to generate an even more accurate assessment of traffic congestion levels for the metropolitan areas.  Such assessment would lead to the development of effective policies to reduce traffic congestion levels, which would then contribute to cost savings for both governments and drivers.
